For this experiment, a ground-based computer is programmed to put ATS-6 through a series of attitude maneuvers utilizing the spacecraft's Radio Frequency 13-123 Interferometer, the Attitude Control System, and the Spacecraft Propulsion System. These include precision pointing to fixed targets, slewing between targets, tracking of moving targets, and the generation of prescribed ground tracks. This experiment is expected to lay the necessary foundation for the development of future ground-based spacecraft control systems which would perform many of the essential functions now performed onboard the spacecraft. As a result, reliability could be improved because the ground-base systems could be repaired, or replaced in case of malfunction. Further, the weight and space savings resulting from smaller onboard control systems could be used for redundant or improved power and sensor systems. Future ground-based control systems could provide more versatility in that new tasks could be programmed and performed as requirements or technology changed. Principal Investigator: William C.
